The Sensations of Paradise Kiss
That kick that comes in the pre-ED when you hear the vocals of Franz Ferdinand blaring over whatever dramatic punctuation that they’ve set up for you. Of all the pre-ED kicks I know these are just about the toppest of the tops. When I think of Franz Ferdinand I think Take Me Out and the post-punk chorus that stiffens into crazy machinery that you just have to pump your feet to.
The little dance that cartoon Yukari does in the ED. While usually I skip EDs and OPs, I always watch to that part somehow, and usually beyond that. That this EDalways punctuates the dramatic motions is probably the complete opposite of that feeling you get when the chiptune-esque electric chime kicks in at the end of Shinsekai Yori. That song represents a downward flowing melancholy, but this is always an upwards flowing motion.


Unlike some other anime I know, the upwards flowing motion always hits the ending section correctly. We don’t get any Clannad dissonantic schisms.


The sketchy drawings of the characters as magazine fronts, each representing different fashion subcultures. Elle, Doll 10, Time and Zipper.


Watching that OP that makes it look completely like a NANA thing, but then realizing that it’s completely the opposite of a NANA thing.


Seeing the weird cut-into-life opening portion that always mixes strange animals and things with real life shots of the city. While Yukari will ruminate poetic over some aspect of the strange void of her life.


The one word I could always feel when watching Paradise Kiss was Naturalism. It doesn’t fail to kick you right in the face, when you expect a gripping plot involving pretty boys and stylish moaning damsels, and suddenly your main character devolves from a shoujo girl into this slapstick deformed thing running jokily for her life.


Voice Acting that is completely off to any notion of stylish dramatic gesture. Long stretches without any background music except diegetic noise. Everything strikes as cool, composed, organic.


It does a screen wipe with a weird sound effect whenever changing scenes. Do you know how off-putting this is? In a good way of course. Akira Kurosawa did the same thing in his films. But when you see a bunch of weird animals swimming past the screen you know this anime definitely wasn’t made for any astounding dramatic flourish. Every cut feels like a cut of life, in its truest sense.


Fashion is the main. Everyone’s Fashion is so absurdly gaudy, like a Vivienne Westwood showcase.


How Kobayashi works: The scene where Yukari gets slapped by her mother is told in monologue over a shot of a house. It isn’t shown until later, and it has no impact, and she herself doesn’t feel anything in particular from it except mild resentment. 


Things happen at a crazy fast pace, but so perfectly positioned that you feel 12 episodes is just exactly enough. How it does this is that it never lingers on dramatic moments, although everything in here screams NANA melodramatic. It figures that the most important thing is to show the process of a character’s interior growth, and that is does, with her sensations towards the things happening around her, with her rumination over the possibilities of her growth, and with nothing else in mind.


Silent cravings, of love, or passion, or meaning, are shown with a dignity, that at best will only be reflected as silent moans, or cries, or longings, but never the type that strikes purposely to pull at heartstrings. Just about the most devastating thing that happens in the last episode is so undercut that it’s completely chilling. It’s amazing too that the issue is solved by the same episode.


When it earns the dramatic moments, these are actually hard earned. The most obvious being the well projected in advance Fashion Exhibition.


You have to love the focus on the small things, such as the slow dyeing of blue flowers, or stringing together a butterfly ring. The small essentially small acts which everything grand is based on. 


You could say that Kobayashi works in a style that is essentially similar to the stringing together of a butterfly ring. Small pearls, in moments, actions, shots, and atmospheric ellipsis, are strung together into something so gaudy and powerful that the whole package feels vaster than anything else out there. Even the throbbing life and décor built through the slow culmination of streetside noise patterns, silent wafting through baroque cafes, and strolling through elaborate fashion sets, all feel immaculately made to sharpen your senses to the loving guiding hand that goes into such creation.


After realizing all of the miniscule stuff that goes into pattern design, go Google search an Alexander McQueen dress. Really just capital-L Look at every single detail that exists on that ephemeral piece of cloth.


Langsam Blut. Shoegaze. Spectaculariffic. Which director knows perfectly what songs to use at where-ever?


You know you can always say that certain works will leave a never-loosening pit in your gut, because these works have specially tailored an escape for you such that when you get out of the world you feel nothing but a yawning gulf inside that forces you to hunger for more. How many things can do what Paradise Kiss can do and reverse engineer that process, so that you come out feeling even more full?

Story and character:
I saw this anime a while back, and caught myself thinking about it long after I finished it years ago. This is a generally good sign and I'm glad I can say that George is one of the most memorable characters in anime. The story itself is about Yukari, and while I like how the plot brings out her insecurities and develop her confidence, I was captivated by George. He's a brilliant creation: bold, straight-forward, unyielding, decisive, and cool. These are traits many anime writers want to imbue into their male leads, but while some succeed, many do fail - yet what makesGeorge such a great success it that not only is he masculine in having these traits, he is a bisexual clothing designer. His character holds both feminine and masculine details that blur the lines between gender identity. And even better, he is not some gay caricature. This is a person you want leading your team.


The supporting cast is also nothing to scoff at. Since this story focuses on individuality with an emphasis on Japanese counter-culture, the supporting cast are self sustained and believable people. Yukari, being the center of the story, undergoes a coming of age. It is to be expected that she will be annoying at times because she is so insecure about her life and decisions, but overall, her vulnerability contrasts well with George's strength. It also does well to show George's role as the fairy-god mother figure. He is cruel and curt at times, but for a spineless girl like Yukari, George is coldness proved to be the necessary push in the right direction. 


Art and Sound:


Loved the art and loved the music. The Intro is some upbeat Japanese pop song that really sets the mood. The ED is a Franz Ferdinand song so I appreciated that. The art is above and beyond. Wonderful bright colors that are used to define the character's personalities. Artistic freedom with some some of the street scenes. It's not an action anime so I didn't expect amazing fluidity, but I liked that the characters weren't too stiff and had dynamic positioning. 


Overall Enjoyment: 


It's a very good anime. Good for those turbulent teenage years and I'm hesitant to say it, but George had a bit of an impact on me. The plot isn't too out-of-this-world complex. It's about young people finding the determination to take the first big, bold step towards their dreams. Yet, it is sensitive while maintaining a no-nonsense perspective into dealing with all those nice feelings teenagers develop. It excites a little bit of rebellion into the hearts of its viewers. In the end, what I found most memorable was George tinge of cruelty. He has a light bitter taste to him that makes him more enigmatic than his amazing style and carefree sex life.

It has been a true honour to have been able to experience this anime.
The story is about a young girl, Yukari, who is questioning who she wants to be. She feels as though the career ahead of her isn't what she wants. Yukari then gets a taste of the world of fashion through the new 'paradise kiss' clothing brand and takes a liking to it. She also experiences her first love through a seemingly cold man named George.
Story 9/10 - The story was beautiful. It was definitely different from what I was expecting. It felt so mature which many animes lack these days. It lackeda sense of adventure but it ruled over the slice of life genre.  The ending wasn't perfect, as much as I wished it. Yet, I feel as though there couldn't have been a better ending. It was truly amazing.  


Animation 10/10 - The art of this anime is what stood out to me. It was really a job well done. The style shocked me at first because the bodies and faces were actually proportional *gasp*. The characters were beautiful and so detailed. The piercings and the gorgeous clothing was what stood out to me. If I didn't give this a 10 just for the clothing itself, it will haunt me until I change it.

One thing I thought didn't fit into the theme was when the characters turned into ballon heads, it was strange and I thought it didn't suit the mood at times.


Music 8/10 - Somehow I thought the music wasn't as up to standards. Even though the OP and ED were exceptional,  catchy and suited the anime (thus the 8), there was a complete lack of background music. I think it was because they wanted to keep it more realistic. Though, in my opinion it didn't work because I felt as though a mood was lacking. I didn't know how to react during certain scenes. I felt like I was reading a LN. I also noticed that at certain points when a faint background song can be heard, it was misplaced. Nonetheless,  the ending theme was so good so I cannot say anymore.


Characters 9/10 - The characters were fairly good. I admit that I loved George's personality, he was different to many other characters. He was uncaring and thoughtless without being a tsundere. Yukari was a decent heroine. I have to say I would have never stayed with George for the time she lasted. She seemed like a pushover at times but redeemed herself with her will and beauty during other scenes. The supporting characters were all likable and relatable. 


Overall 9/10 - I truly enjoyed this anime. I had an amazing experience. The only reason it has lost a point is because of the lack of emotion Paradise Kiss pulled out of me. I completely recommed it to anyone over 16, it has a few sexual references and scenes. Definitely will revisit this anime in the future, it has pulled me into the fashion genre.

*Don't expect plot summary from this review!*
(Note: I was way too harsh on this when I first reviewed it. I've since re-watched it and really found it to be considerably better the second time around--so this review may get re-written at some point!)
Not really my cup of tea. It does have a lot of redeeming values--the background art is frequently lovely, and the clothing designs for the characters (and how often they are changed) is to be admired--oftentimes anime characters are only given an outfit or two and just cycle through them, much to the relief of the animators, no doubt. That said, some ofthe more extravagant outfits here are barely animated at all--annoyingly enough, this includes the ornate dress the characters have spent the entire series hand-crafting. When we finally see it it's mostly only in still frames, or with the model wearing it being shown simply bobbing up and down as she walks. Granted, I know essentially nothing about runway fashion, but it seems to me that part of the appeal about an outfit like this would be the way it behaves as it's actually being worn and moved in, so it's disappointing to lose that dimension of the experience. \n\n
That aside, the characters are fine for the most part, though they largely remain pretty firmly rooted in anime stereotypes. There are some exceptions, which are especially noticeable in the minor characters--all of whom are more interesting than the primary protagonist, whom I actively disliked. By and large she's a typical anime heroine--klutzy, lovesick, unsure of herself, etc.--this is made up for eventually when she manages to grow a bit of a spine, but the fact that she occasionally goes into complete bitch mode doesn't really make me any more invested in her ultimate fate. Unfortunately, the side characters aren't explored to the same level of detail that she is, and the writers cheat a bit by making at least two of them very wealthy--which explains how they can get away with everything that they do without suffering much in the way of personal or social consequences.\n\n
The series also doesn't quite know when to end--the denouement stretches on for at least a full episode longer than it should, though at least it works hard to wrap up pretty much any questions fans should have about the fates of the characters they've spent so much time with up to this point. All in all, it's a fine coming-of-age story, and its frank (well, PG-13 frank) explorations of teenage lust are worthy of praise. I was ultimately underwhelmed by it on the whole, but I could see it having a stronger effect on others, particularly young women. This is a series I would not hesitate to recommend to a 13-year old girl, which is something I rarely find myself unable to say about many anime series I watch.

This is my first rewiev since I joined here and I don`t know when I will write another.
A friend of mine recomended it for me and when I saw the title I was expecting anything: between hentai and madness and still, the show took me by surprise.
The series has 12 episodes, and is part of the Romance genre, but I think it's more than that. After you watch the first episodes, you'll find it sounds more interesting than the title, which is the name of fashion houses.
Story
The story is centered around a student, Caroline (Yukari Hayasaka), who is noticed by a group of designers, andis proposed to be a model and present their creations. She rejects the idea initially, especially after she sees Arashi, a punkhead with piercings, who runs after her. After passing out at the sight of Isabelle, who was dressed as a widow, Caroline reach designers shop, which will become their place of entertainment for the next period of her life. She befriends rather quickly with Miwako, younger sister of a famous clothing designer, and is impresed by George, who is the manager of the whole team and the one dealing with all Parakiss creations, their own brand of clothing. Together with them, Caroline will spend the period before exams, and eventually will have to choose what path to follow in life.\n\n
Graphics\n
The graphic style of this anime is a little different of the  "clasic" style, especially on the characters level. These have features much closer to reality, girls characters have more lines than we are accustomed from other animes  and, as you will see, this increases their expressiveness. The animators did a great job with graphics. The characters are drawn almost perfectly consistent, regardless of angle, position or even hair and clothes. These last two elements are specifically mentioned.\n
When a character changes the arrangement of hair, it remains perfectly recognizable, but at the same time is deeply different, much like in reality.\n
In terms of character clothes, and considering the subject, Paradise Kiss is impressive: most of the characters change their clothes very often (as would be\n
expected from them) and clothes (and accessories) they are very great designed.\n
In another chapter defining graphics, backgrounds, Paradise Kiss is somewhere in the middle level. Backgrounds are generally well worked and occasionally beautifully detailed, but rarely impresses.\n\n
Sound \n
The soundtrack was one of the impressive things in this anime, because I've rarely met songs so well rhythmic and exciting.\n
The OP and the ED fit perfectly with the atmosphere and characters in this series, and this time, I liked both. The OP is called "Lonely in Gorgeous" and is composed and performed by Tommy february6 and the ED is called "Do you Want to ", and is played by Franz Ferdinand. \n
Marika Matsumoto plays Miwako. Her voice is most remarkable because it seems much younger than she is (22 years). Hiroaki Sano was Music Producer for the series Jyu Oh Sei (another great OP), and the music was made by The Babys group, and with Narasaki voice from Coaltar of the Deepers.\n
Almost always you will hear the noise of the city in crowded places, the people who speak or cars passing on the street.\n
Otherwise, you will hear most often the heavy metal that Arashi is listening in the workshop, and you will also hear the "Ballad of Arashi".\n

What I like about this anime is that, the romantic story is one of the most realistic ones that I've seen. It's not a fairy tale type anime, but yet it still tugs at your heart. 
Quriky and original, you could see this anime being someone's actual life. It's fun, funky and a pleasure to watch. 
With tons of fashion, drama, and interesting characters, this show doesn't have a boring episode. 
I wasn't a fan of the art in the beginning, but it grew on me as the anime progressed. I think it perfectly suits the tone of the anime, and the characters themselves. Brightand quirky! Two words that perfectly describe everything about this anime. 


The ending wasn't at all what I expected, but it was very fitting, it is realistic and makes sense, considering what had happened throughout the show. It left me satisfied with the conclusion. 


It's short, but I think for the story line, a longer series would have dragged and lost the wonderful upbeat momentum. I don't think it would have really been able to go anywhere had it been longer. 


The dub is fairly good, most of the voices match their personalities very well. 


If you want something light and easy, but enjoyable to watch then I would recommend this!

At this point in time, Studio Madhouse was starting to feel the weight of the industry pressing down on them. Pumping out the amount of anime that they were just meant they could not keep up both quality and production. For this reason, it was around this time in late 2005 where Madhouse started to slow down a bit, and begin to look for alternative ways for anime production. Paradise Kiss is actually a sequel set within the same universe as the show Neighborhood Stories from the mid-90’s and is a standalone story from it as well. Returning Madhouse Director and person who likes tobe part of everything involved with the anime he works on is Osamu Kabayashi (Beck). 


Yukari Hayasaka is in her final year of high school and is pretty much bored with life. She does not care much about which university she ends up. All she wants is to get out of town and do something different with her life. This is where by happenstance she runs into a group of college fashion design students that want her to be a model for their final project. After some convincing, Yukari agrees to the task and slowly learns and gets engrossed into the world of the fashion industry.


Almost immediately the audience can see the similarities between Paradise Kiss and Beck (2004): same director/studio, still frames, heavily detailed in the theme of the show, silent settings for characters, and it is more of a teen drama. Basically, Paradise Kiss is an unconventional unique anime. However, it suffers from similar faults as well: bland backgrounds, awkward moments without a reason, a strangely rushed conclusion, and weak romance elements.


What are the strengths to Paradise Kiss? That starts and ends with how clothing, body language, and the fashion is presented. The characters are presented extremely detailed from something as simple as a few strands of hair falling over an eye to the outstanding detail of clothing texture with authentic designs. This show also shows a pretty good portrayal of a teenager struggling to find their reason and purpose in the world. Yukari learning what it means to takes risks towards a passion, learning the difference between a fling and love, and what it means to grow up are all great examples of a protagonist’s struggle. Even the other characters in the main cast have unique portrayals. In particular, the character George whom has bi-sexual and sadomasochistic tendencies, the anime tends to focus more on his passion for the fashion industry than his alternative life choices.


Paradise Kiss is one of the most unique examples of an anime breaking away from the norm. It truly represents a slice of life focusing on something other than a hard-romance. Everything in this show seems to be new and refreshing at the same time. There just isn’t enough of these kinds of anime and Paradise Kiss is one of those that a typical anime fan will need an open mind to dive into.

This review is mainly intended to convince people to watch this anime (don't read the ending section) but also for finished watchers. I mainly talk about characters here. 
I'm writing this review right after I finished the 12th episode, and I've got a lot to say about this beautiful, beautiful piece of work. Its just so realistic, touching, and inspiring. I loved how they portrayed the physical aspect of relationships, because it just made the show so much more believable, and REAL. I will cut the chase and keep my review as succinct as possible, even though I can probably talk about for ages.
George-- So a lot of people call him an asshole, but to be honest, I think George is one of the best male characters/boyfriend ever. Now his crude and sometimes emotionally ruthless personality really does characterize him as a dick(player and all, apparently he also had a boyfriend??), there is no doubt in the fact that he inspired Yukari to be who she is by the end of the show. He was someone who encouraged her to be independent, tell all the haters to f*** off, and believe in herself. His incredibly liberal attitude got me shook, because its rare to see such a mature character who has very 'western' ideals. He only does what he wants to do, and pursues his own dreams, regardless of what the society or people around him say. To me, George was an incredibly inspiring character, in addition to being a total gaudy, hot, billionaire (His family is LOADED its insane). 


Miwako - At first, she just seemed to be a typical pink haired loli with a really high pitched voice, but in the end, I really liked Miwako. I consider her kind of like that cute, happy friend that just cheers everybody else up. 


Arashi - piercings and band and fashion! Yes! At first, Arashi seems like that boorish, angsty teen you don't want to talk to. However, he is surprisingly pure and loyal. He is loyal to his friends, his love music, his love for Miwako, and his beliefs. I love his relationship with Miwako, especially the moment when he says that sex isn't what makes him happy. His like a gigantic teddy bear on the inside and definitely BFF material. The song he sang for Miwako was so heart touching I legit hugged the computer screen.


Isabella - An unique, transgender character. Unique, yes, but still realistic as hell. Though short, the flashback to her childhood as a boy with George was enough to give depth and meaning to this character. His struggle with her gender was on point, and how George gave him the dress was a genius way of establishing their friendship.(Again, why George is AWESOME) Isabella was like the mature mom of the group. She always gives consort to people around her. You can't hate Isabella. And of course she just also happens to be loaded and GORGEOUS. 


Hiroyuki -- A sensible, likeable character. Honestly if everybody were to be like Hiroyuki, the world would be a better place. I'm not gonna talk about manga spoilers, but from what I read this guy had a happy ending. 


Finally, Yukari -- I love her character. The development in Yukari was astonishing. From her lack of motivation in life and family pressure to her current model self, the process was well written and again, so realistic. Personality wise, I couldn't find anything annoying about her *surprise surprise. She is usually calm and levelheaded, not over dramatic, have great work ethic and an amazing attitude towards life. I love her interactions with George too. She's a female MC that can stand her ground, and I respect her for that.


The characters are what made this anime so enjoyable. So I won't waste my time talking about the story, because the plot is for you to discover and all I've got to say is that its well written and developed. and have an inspirational message. 

Music was good. Arashi's song was amazing. But otherwise, it did its job. The opening had a super catchy intro. 

Art: it was such a turn off sometimes. So Madhouse was experimenting with some weird photographic inserts as backgrounds, which was more evident in the first few episodes (THANK GOD), like I know you're trying to be unique and hyperrealistic, sometimes it just looked downright awkward. The black, faded out transition cuts were sometimes super awkward too. 

Otherwise, the characters were animated with care. I loved how expressive the eyes and eyebrows were. 


ENDING:

The first thing I thought of was the movie LaLa land. Yukari and George doesn't end up together. Now people might be mad about it, honestly I was happy about it. Because it was exactly what George(notably) and other characters stood for. This idea that they are all walking their separate paths. If Yukari went to Paris with George, this would mean to contradict her own beliefs. Thank GOD she stays to pursue her modeling career. Life isn't perfect. Life is full of sacrifices. 

I mean, why should watchers even complain when even George said to Yukari: "That's the right choice/answer!" when he asked her if she wanted to come with him to Paris. 

**This didn't mean I wasn't balling at the end though. 


All in all, this was a masterpiece. The only reason why it wasn't a 10 was because of the issues regarding art I had mentioned above. Otherwise, it takes the crown of being the best romance/drama anime I've ever watched.

Just to start off I'll say this..
The artwork just from the pictures I previewed before watching this anime really threw me off, I found the style distasteful, but, after watching the first episode you can clearly see that this is  an intentional unique style of the artist and they do have a lot of talent.
This anime really took me by surprise I am usually too lazy to write reviews even of my favorite anime but it shocked me so much I had to talk about it. I started out just looking for a decent anime to tide me over for the night, I hadn'tput much effort into my anime search, I just went for the first thing that popped up on josei romance search. But one episode came after another and then another and before I knew it it was over and part of my soul was missing.\n\n
I just binged watched this whole series in the last few hours and didn't even realize it until that devastating ending. (spoiler alert) SERIOUSLY WHO ENDS A SHOW THAT WE HAVE STRUGGLED THROUGH TOGETHER WITH OUR EMOTIONS RUNNING DEEP WITH AN ENDING THAT IS SUCH A SLAP IN THE FACE. I really really appreciate the realness and maturity of this story, it is so relate-able on a very deep level but GOD can we not get an ending that rewards us so this emotional roller coaster we have just been through? I get it, emphasis on the realness but this is a story, an escape from our real shitty lifes. If we can't get our own happy endings at least we can watch our beloved characters get theirs.!!!..I'm just ranting because I didn't get my way but this really was an amazing anime that I didn't expect to leave such an impression on me.

I finished paradise kiss in one day, which is quick for me even though there are only 12 episodes, but I can't say I liked watching it. It was inspiring, sure, and the art was great, but from the beginning to the end I felt an underlying bitterness that I couldn't get out of. 
NO SPOILERS AHEAD
THE CHARACTERS 
So, even though some of the interaction in paradise kiss was more realistic than in other shoujo anime, I never got to liking the characters. The main girl didn't really have anything going for her and her love interest was extremely selfish. The fact that they fellin love felt unrealistic to me, the love itself felt more like lust and infatuation, too insecure and I personally just didn't see the point. Even though the other characters were reasonably interesting, I found that the little backstory they got was rushed, and I never got to liking them either. No-one made me smile and I wasn't particularly rooting for anyone. I think the makers were going for a realistic vibe, but part of life is the fun and I didn't have it, and I never really saw the characters have it. So why did I keep watching?


FASCINATION 

Most stories I love are the ones that have great characters, reasonably realistic and lovable. And though I think these were meant to be lovable or at least have some appeal they all seemed desperate to me. It missed one of the essential parts that I look for: Comfort. I need a bit of hope and comfort, a great friendship or deep trust or a love story that isn't just driven by passion. When none of that is there it just sort of drags on for me. I did keep watching, not really because I wanted to know about the characters but because I got fascinated by the feeling that it gave me. Somehow I just got an incredible feeling of growing bitterness and despair from every episode. I didn't really care about the story but it did teach me things about what I absolutely don't want from life. I'm a songwriter and I paused several times to write songs because it gave me that feeling of at least knowing my own priorities and goals. They were all pretty dark songs. I certainly found it interesting to watch but I'm never going to watch it again. It's just something I wanted finished, but the fact that I didn't stop proved that I was fascinated, which is why the score isn't dramatic. 


BE WARNED

Don't go in expecting a happy go lucky anime, I know, I probably already made that pretty clear. I don't think everyone finds it depressing, but I do, and it kept eating away at me. I get that some people love this anime, and some who crave realism might find what they are looking for. But personally I didn't find the story all that realistic and it just mostly made me feel kind of empty. To me the world doesn't look anything like it was portrayed (figuratively, not literally of course) I hadn't meant to give it a five but I writing this I just couldn't feel good about these aspects of the anime.


SO ENOUGH DEPRESSING STUFF

The art was, well, ART, it was beautiful, a bit more realistic than most anime and really artistically done. The colors were great, I never once skipped the theme-song-video and it was overall pretty awesome. Some of the same shots were used a few times randomly, which bothered me a bit but I liked it a lot overall. It really fit the story and the vibe too. The music didn't stand out for me but never really bothered me either. 


YOU MIGHT LOVE IT

I do think that some people will love it, it might really just be personal perspective or priorities, it was interesting, beautiful and flamboyant, and I do think the dialogue was well done and more like the actual confused human beings we all are than a lot of other shoujo anime. I just couldn't see the point in the choices the characters made and I didn't believe them to be real, so the dialogue sort of drowned in that frustration. The anime left me feeling a little hollow which could be either a good sign or a bad sign, I'm not sure yet. 


I hope this helped in making your choice, I can't really recommend it but I can't say you won't love it either so good luck!

Paradise Kiss
 Growing up is probably the hardest part of our lifes. Because when you get older you do not see the world as you used to see. You want to try everything to know what is wrong or what is right. The life always teaches you the best but the hardest way. You don’t have to be 50 to understand the world. Because age is just a number only mistakes get you older. Since I watched Nana, I am a fan of Ai Yazawa. Because until now, she is the only person who made me see a girl’s perspective in a realistic way.
 ParadiseKiss is an anime which aimed for the girl audience but unlike the most of shoujos it is a bit deep for me. You will understand what I want to say while you read:


Story: The story is about a girl named Yukari who only focus on her education and she does not have any intention to be a model until she come across with a group of the fashion design students who want Yukari to be a model for their fashion show. At first, even she does not want to do this, then she becomes friends with the student and her heart is stolen by our main character named George then she decides doing this. But the rest won’t be pink as you think. She will want to discover the real world and it will cause a problem because of the pressure of her family. Then she has to decide which one she will choose: Education or Stepping Into The Life?


Characters: To me, the most important thing about the characters is seeing the development of them. And you will definetly see it and fall in love with the characters. Because every character has own their stories. You will try to empathy to the character especially with Yukari. It was really enjoyable to see Yukari’s growin up.You will ask yourself if you were her what would you do. We will witness Yukari’ choices, George’s stability on his job, the other characters’ facing with the past…Also I think the girl audience will fall in love with George who was created by inspiring Brian Slade from Velvet Goldmine. And this makes George a very charismatic and flirt character.


Art: Ai Yazawa’s art is simply amazing to me. Her design and different drawing style make her an unique artist to me. But for the people who has not seen any work of Ai Yazawa, this type of art might disturb them. Because everything in Ai Yazawa’s works are proportionated 

and glamorous. You can see the characters do not wear the same clothes everyday. And seeing gothic lolitas and rock chicks will make happy the boy audience too. Well at least I became :) Also you can see lots of detail in it: the boys with the  piercings, glamorous and exaggerated clothes, even a crossdresser too. And some of you may  find it weird because of not seeing it in every anime, but the buildings and some places are live action…


Music:  To be honest I was surprised when I first listened the opening and ending song. I was not expecting something like Nana’s but it was better than I expected. Nothing could fit in this anime except indie-rock / post punk type songs and luckily the opening is very suitable to this anime. And after hearing the ending I screamed because the ending song was from Franz Ferdinand which is one of my favouite bands. So if you are into indie music you should check that songs. They are really good.



Originality: It does not have any stereotype in a shoujo anime like the school festival, valentines day etc. Also there can be people who say we could not even see a kiss. Well I can tell you that you will see more than a kiss. And our main character is not a loser. I mean she is rebel and a strong girl to survive to the real world. 


Satisfying Ending: Well, I always talked about the good parts in it. But ending was not satisfying for me. Maybe it is just because I don’t love the unhappy endings. But it made the serie more realistic to me. 


Bad Sides:

-Some events have no connections to each other.

- It was too short and the final episode was not satisfying enough. I mean everything just happened suddenly and I could not keep up. It should have more episodes 

-Some of the scenes were unrealistic to me. Like the relation with Yukari and her mother…


 All in all, Paradise Kiss is an amazing anime for me. And it is one of the best shoujo’s I’ve ever seen. To know what to do in the future and gambling with the fate is really hard. The anime does not say what to do. It gives us options then we decide what to do. As a boy I really enjoyed this, I hope you all enjoy this I did.

I decided to watch Paradise Kiss due to its similarity with Nana- one of my personal favorites for a long time. The story follows the main lead Yukari Hayasaka who’s your typical: type A, devout, hardworking high school student. She’s approached by group of students to model for their high school fashion competition. The story follows her internal, family, and friendship struggle in choosing her own future rather than following what her parents laid out for her. Ai Yazawa, as always, outstands with her beautiful artwork and exceptionally wonderful characters. Each character’s life struggle is reflected in our own, which allows us to deeply bondwith the characters. What I love even more about Ai Yazawa is the fact she shed light on the lgbtq community through her beautiful characters. I was really disappointed with the animation—there were many parts where the animation seemed out of focus or too slow, which is a shame since the artwork was extremely well done. Overall, it was a lovely anime with realistic view on life decisions and relationships.

Paradise Kiss is basically about a girl name Yukari who is tired of her boring old life and want some excitement. Well, she gets it when she gets across one of the designers from a group who designs what is known as "Paradise Kiss". They need a model to represent their dress for the upcoming fashion show so they decide to pick her. Along the way, she meets other characters, falls in love, struggles a relationship with her mother, and finding who and what she can do in her life. 
Story: 
I think Paradise Kiss definitely has a unique storyline to it. Other than theusual love story and friendships, the story about a group of students who dreams of being a fashion designer. One other reason I liked about Paradise Kiss is that the story has more realistic stories into it and not have girls with gigantic boobs or have dragons and talking animals (I'm kind of exaggerating).


Art: 

For me, I thought the producers did an amazing job with the animation. Even though it's not the best quality, not to mention it was aired in 2005, but the details were significant and not to mention the pretty designs they came up with in the show. 


Sound: 

Even though I liked the OP song, the BGM didn't stick out too much for me while I watched the series. And even when I finished the series, I wasn't looking forward to getting the OST or even looking for it. (hm.. now that i think about it, I don't have ANY of the songs from its OST..) 


Character: 

For an 12 episode series, I think they did an amazing job at giving personality to each characters. There's the tough guy, the cool guy, the confused girl, the cute innocent girl, and bunch of different character. And I admit, I couldn't help but like every single character in the series. It's one of those series where you just have to understand and accept their personality and not complain about it, espcially at the end since alot of people didn't agree to it. 


Overall: 

I enjoyed watching this series and it's kinda disappointing that I watched it not so long ago, and not when it first came out. If you're into romance and just a everyday life story, then this one's definitely for you. Finally, Paradise Kiss gave me a good life lesson personally. Hopefully, it will do the same for whoever watches it 


c:

Painfully and beautifully realistic. 
It's a great blend between search of what you want from live, about love, hard work, dreams and patterns of life.
I'm more fan of classic anime drawing style, but after first episode I loved it. 
The characters are very classic, but easy to fall for. The art is inspiring, and the story it self leads to think about your own life choices, why we do what we do, and, in my opinion, it's the definitions of great anime, if in the end, you not only enjoy watching it, but also it stirs questions about yourself. 
The love story is not themain object of all anime, which is great. And, like i said in the begging, it's painfully realistic, it shows how relationships aren't just about romance, it's also how they help grow and how they change person inside. \n
The ending killed me little bit, but hey, that's life, and any how you look at it, it's beautiful. \n\n
I'm still heartbroken, but I'm also in love with this anime. \n

I figured I knew what I was getting into when I read what Paradise Kiss was about. I like shojo manga and this one looked like a classic one. While what I did get was entertaining and typically shojo in many aspects, it was also a little disappointing and fell flat at times.
Story- The story wasn't bad, and i think overall it was a very interesting take on a typical school story. The modeling aspect gave the story a distinction from all the other similar high school love stories. My biggest issue with the story was how it ended. I won't spoil anything, but Ifelt like there were many many loose ends that weren't elaborated on. And while I have watched anime with a mysterious cliffhanger type of ending that did work, this one didn't. I was just left asking too many questions and wondering why the final episode didn't feel like a last episode at all until the last 5 minutes.


Art- The art is pretty, and a nice adaptation of the manga style. I thought it fit the high fashion style the story was about and the over dramatic clothes and hairstyles really fit in to the scenes well. While the art was pretty, there were visible hiccups in the animation and it didn't always flow as well as it could have.


Sound- The music was good, and the opening and ending songs fit the type of show this is. But one of the things that drove me crazy was the English dub voice acting. Yukari and George, the two main characters, both had voices that were overdone and silly. While there were a few actors I recognized and enjoyed their performance, they were often minor characters who didn't get much screen time. The main cast was a little annoying to listen to, and all seemed very forced. 


Character- I did NOT like George. Still don't. But that doesn't really affect my score for character. Yukari's personality was very similar to a good natured teenager who goes on a rebellious streak and something good comes out of it (her modeling). But George just seemed like an ass to me. He never really changed enough throughout the course of the show to grow on me. Most of the other characters were typical or boring in my opinion, but I can see some of them (like Miwako) being a likable character to many people. 


Enjoyment- I felt a little bored through a lot of the show, and I didn't care much for the level of progression that was set. But it wasn't a bad show, and I did like it. In the end it was worth watching, even though I would likely never watch it again.

I'm not saying this is horrible but i didn't enjoy most of it.  They just made George such an asshole and Yukari an idiot!! I was more interested in miwako's love triangle than George's push and pull act. If you can look past the bad romance it's a pretty cute friendship story. plus theres a cannon trans woman and they're too rude about it. they treat her more as a drag queen though :/
I personally thought the last 4 episodes were the best so if you can make it through 8 eps of Yukari being an absolute idiot you'll finally enjoy this mess lol.

Story - 4 
Caroline stumbles across a group of fashion students who want them to model for her, within that there's a lot of romance/drama (with nudity) going on within the anime. In my opinion, the storyline is quite rushed and even though it's a 12 episode anime therefore there's not enough episodes to make a complex story, I feel like this anime develops the storyline quite badly as it jumped from one thing to the next rather randomly. However the flaws in the story made it quite entertaining because I'd find myself laughing at how random it was. Despite this, I did enjoy theending. 


Art - 7

Nice art, nothing out of the ordinary but there are a lot of different type of characters from typical "girly, cute" looking characters to others with piercings etc.


Sound - 9 

Really good music that definitely fits the anime. The ending theme song is a Franz Ferdinand song, who I personally really like.


Character - 3

The character development is rather poor and does not allow time for me, as a viewer to develop any emotional attatchment to the storyline. 


Enjoyment - 6

It's a decent anime, I found myself laughing a lot at the cringey parts of it and how random it was.


Overall - 6

I watched it because I really enjoyed NANA and was recommended to watch this but personally I don't think it's anything like NANA for character development and plot development other than similar looking characters.

I give this story a 10. I watched it because it was recommended if you enjoyed the anime Nana created by Ai Yawaza. Her stories are always powerful and have a lot of different and unique characters to relate to. The plot was wonderful. For other being only 12 episodes, I was worried that the story would be sped up with alot of confusion but no, perfect pace and it ended nicely. Some people didn't agree with the ending but I say it was satisfying once you realize the meaning of everything that happens on this anime.
For the art, very realistic. And also, alot ofpeople hate seeing an anime with a bunch of characters that look the same and hard to follow. Everyone here are unique and have their own distinctive look. Different voices, they all don't sound the same. Also, this anime is about fashion, so the different styles of clothing they create here is pretty nice too. Some people thought it's ugly or old fashion but people need to remember that this is an older done anime. Fashion sense were different then. I seen what was being portrayed with the art given here. The main character, Caroline is changing and learning new things about her and how to control her life, so in each episode her fashion sense grows as well as her maturity and independence.


For sound, the opening song isn't too bad. I know it's called Lonely in Gorgeous. Also, since I watched the anime Nana English dubbed, I did the same for this anime to see if the voices were sorta similar or the same. They were similar. I watched it English sub and their voices fit well with the characters too.. the little music that is played in the background fits well with the scenes. Nothing that jumps out, most noticeable songs played are the intro and outro.


For the characters, I am only going to do the main character because I am trying not to spoil it.. Yukari aka Caroline, she's basically the main character. Her mom is very strict on her and for her 18 years all she's done is study to become the best in school, for her mother. Once her new friends discovered her inner talent before she could, she then elopes for several days. Confident in her choices. Trying to find what exactly she wants for herself, and no one else. How to be your own person and not make excuses or blame others for the decisions you make. The relationship she goes through with her boyfriend George and her other fashion friends helps her grow up and become an adult. Not knowing she actually had someone in her corner to give her advice, she gets herself together and do things the right way. She's also given an ultimatum but does not regret her decisions. Everything is a learning experience and viewers can relate to her because it's something that everyone faces in their life. But she actually had the courage to not follow in anyone's footsteps except her own. It was either a beginning of a new love or beginning of a new career. The message was very powerful on the last episode and it's not a sad one, it's a realistic ending with no sugar coating.


George, Yukari boyfriend and also head of fashion line Paradise Kiss, I felt that the creator made viewers wishy washy with him. The whole time you think he's being a fake controlling person but overall he was very kind, thoughtful and sweet to Yukari. There are a lot of things left unsaid about him that makes you not like him so much but can see how much love the both of them had for each other. These two are the ones you will remember the most. The other characters are great as well. I love all of them and all of them have their own story which I love. You get to know where they all come from from , flashbacks occur as well and the passion they all have and strive for.


All and all, I love a anime that is realistic and that I can relate to. I don't really like short animes but the message is powerful and universal. I recommend this anime and it's one of those you would watch again. I hope my review helped out and I hope whomever that reads would watch it and get a taste of how well put together it is.

Short and to the point review:
The year is 2018 and I randomly decide to watch "Paradise Kiss" which was aired +10 years ago. How does it compare with today's anime standards?  Pretty well I must say.
Story: 8/10
The main story themes are Romance, Slice of life, adult themes and Drama. We follow final year high school student Yukari who wanders through life not knowing what she wants. Blessed with good looks, Yukari one day is asked to model for a group of fashion students for their final project.  
Animation: 7/10 
Compared to today's anime standards, Paradise Kiss' animation is quite good. For sure youcan tell the animation is "out dated" but it was good enough to not bother me.


Sound: 6/10

Sound wasn't impactful but nor was it an issue. In other words, it had little influence on how I feel about Paradise Kiss. The opening and ending themes are quite memorable.


Characters: 8/10

We have an interesting mix of unique characters each with their own background stories and life struggles. I'm sure most people watching can relate in some way to each character's experiences.


Enjoyment: 8/10

It was a fun and interesting series. Going through each episode was not an problem and I was keen every time for the next episode.


Final thoughts:

I recommend Paradise Kiss for mature audiences. Perhaps those aged +17 can better appreciate Paradise Kiss because of the many life lessons the show displays. I give the show a 8/10.

Paradise Kiss could've been as great as Nana was.
Right of the heels of my favorite Josei-Drama and listening to that Opening, I knew I had to watch Paradise Kiss as well, a well-cared-for child of noitaminA with an ending by Franz Ferdinand.
And for the most part, the heart and personality of these characters really pull the show.
Sure, some of them aren't nearly as realistic as the others, like the sisters Mikako and Miwako, one of which looks 14 despite being in her mid 30s and the other that still has me debating whether or not she was supposed to be a cute ditz girl oractually mentally challenged.


But on the other hand, George, Yukari and especially Isabella are especially well-written and realistic characters in contrast and all of them have interesting lives who just happened to intermingle. 

A beautiful young man with sometimes very ambiguos motives interested in fashion with a very estrangered relationship to his family, a girl who feels the need to break out of her normalcy, but mostly ends up asking others what to do and struggling to find her own way, and a beautiful woman set on her path by a certain impactful connection in her past and present.


The story is tailored to fit these characters especially well, too - they carry it in its entirety. It's just what happens when these characters come together, kind of like Baccano is carried by being as wild and badass a show as most of its characters are. It's all very natural and these people bounce off of each other very nicely.

This show also has a lot of style very reminiscent of the early 2000s and you can tell its author really loves and cares deeply about fashion.


But despite all these elements covered - in my book some of the most important aspects when watching an Anime - the show still ended up pretty underwhelming.

The main problem is the noticeably rushed pacing and its many time skips as well as the production and lackluster presentation in general.


This show really would have greatly profited from a 20-episode run to balance these elements better and show more out of the life of these characters, give them room to breathe. Isabella especially suffered from this, as one of the most interesting characters next to George, but once her "secret" if you want to call it that is revealed, she kind of falls by the wayside. Same goes for the relationship between Miwako and Arashi - whom I haven't mentioned before because he is, while still likable, probably the least interesting character of the bunch.


Looking at this show however... while the character designs and outfits are beautiful and the general setting feels authetic, especially the bar these characters spend most of the time in, you can really tell that the author was still working on her style that had not fully come into its own. There are quite a few super-deformed moments for comedic purposes, but almost all of them fall flat. Aesthetic aside, some of the timing with these really doesn't go together with the more naturalistic voicework in most of these.

They're also not that well integrated. What was probably just a small panel on the edge of the page in the Manga now goes full center and the contrast feels a bit jarring at times.


There are also a lot of awkward transitions between scenes that drag on for long enough to distract.

There's no snap to the change between scenes most of the time and it makes the whole show feel kinda sloppy and slow.


It's one of those shows I feel conflicted about because I can see its heart and intentions that are my kind of thing, but it's all so washed down with the poor production and other small problems that I can't enjoy it as much as I think I should.


It was worth watching, and I'm happy this helped the author to show so much of her understanding and interest in Nana, but as it stands, it's an unpolished diamond not allowed to shine as brightly as it could have.

It is obviously not the idea to compare animes with each other but ParaKiss was a little bit of a disappointment. Don't get me wrong I still loved it and thought about it a lot when I was not watching. It even kept me from other work that I needed to do. 
However with a series like Nana I expected a little more. They could have done so much if they only changed the amount of episodes there were available. Twelve is not enough for a series like Paradise Kiss. They needed at least 24 and even if they covered the same amount of thisstory it would have still be enough. A little more flashbacks was something that would make me love the characters a little more and understand them a little bit better. For example I loved Isabella/Izabella, and it was a bit weird to get the flashback or the background of her story so late and at one point that it didn't make sense. Why was it necessary there and couldn't you get a glimpse of a flashback earlier on when Miwako said that you couldn't change in front of the boys, which should have brought a big question mark. Anything else but the end. 


I loved the theme and that also reminded me a little of NaNa, which is also the reason why I started to watch Paradise Kiss. Because I love the art from the Nana series and obviously love the art from ParaKiss. The details for music, clothing in both series is absolutely terrific! Which brings me to the next subject: in Nana it is clear why they put so much attention to both clothing and music. Which they don't do with Paradise Kiss, yes the clothing is explained but the idea of Arashi in a band, that could use some extra background again. Same between about the fights between Hiro, Arashi and Miwako. Arashi said he stole Miwako, flashblack please. 


It had so much potential to only miss out because of the fact that it could only have twelve options. So I would say that skipping the anime is a way better job to do and read the manga, than the other way around. What I have done at this point. 

I will read the manga, might be in a year because I don't want to keep repeating for myself. But I'm almost 100% assured that the manga will be so much better.

I went into this anime completely blind, I had no idea what it would be about. But soon after seeing the art style I became very skeptical and slowly turnt more negative each episode. But that only lasted until about episode 3 or 4, which for an anime that only consists of 12 episodes, is pretty long. But still I kept watching, for reasons unknown to me something was pulling me in, making me want to keep watching. Which I did and then bam in the blink of an episode I liked it all of a sudden, I started being able to appreciate all ofthe characters and I loved how you could see them grow throughout the series. After a while it turned out that one of the characters thinks in a pretty similar way to me, which was awesome :) \n
All in all it was a pretty good show, with an heartbreaking ending and I suggest you check it out. You might find yourself liking it more than you may expect.

You know...I don't even know where I picked this one up in the first place, and I certainly never expected it to be this good. This truly was a breath of fresh air, and something decidedly different from any other seinen anime I've ever seen. 
There's something about the story which just kept me hooked until the very end - and yet, it's just about a girl taking matters in her own hands and choosing the job that would truly make her happy. With the persuasion of a few people, of course. The setting is all about fashion, and while you may not be interestedin clothes, this anime puts a very nice twist on it. It all flows very naturally, plus THE DRAMA IS REAL. 


The art itself might turn some people off - and I can understand that, as it's rather unique. But in my opinion, it's beautiful, and as stylish as one of the characters' hand sown dresses. It's very expressive and pleasant to watch.


As for the characters themselves, they were what kept me hooked the most. All of them had their clear faults and realistic personalities, and didn't really have that 'anime' feel to it. I loved every single one of them, got mad at them, cried with them, and I cannot express how satisfying it is to watch some well developed characters who grow and mature beautifully. Their relationships are also both believable and interesting. The romance is wonderfully written, and you can't help but squeal when Yukari and George share their first kiss. There may be times where the characters [the protagonist especially] will make you sigh, though.


The music was rather pleasant, but nothing out of the ordinary. The opening and ending songs were, however, both catchy and fun. Extra points because the ending made me stay.


And to conclude everything, let me tell you this. If you need a break from all the constant fluff and tsunderes, and would rather have something down to earth and realistic, then you should give this one a shot for sure. I don't usually rewatch anime, but this one enraptured me, and I recommend it 100%.

I think at the point of our lives when after high school ends, you’re going to ask yourselves, “What am I going to do with the rest of my life?”, that is if you always think of that a numerous amount of times and you become less of the person you wanted to be and you start to question your way of life.
That’s what Yukari Hayasaki (later being nicknamed “Caroline”) is being described as and it’s no contest about that, especially since it’s beginning to become repetitive and she needed to experience something new and that is when she is encountered with these eccentricfashion design students and they wanted to scout her to become a model for their clothing line Paradise Kiss.




The group consists of Jōji "George" Koizumi, the charismatic student who has a talented gift for fashion design with his extravagant ideas, even if he’s cold at some times, since some of his ideas may not be accepted by the public. Miwako Sakurada is the pink-haired student who works with George and is exceptionally cute and sweet and tends to act child-like manner, either by the dress of the Lolita style and engaging personality. Arashi Nagase is the student with a taste for punk style, piercings (especially around the oral area) and alternative music. He is Miwako’s boyfriend and despite that they seem really unmatched for each other, they have known each other since childhood. Although one of the subplot in the series is that Miwako had feelings for Hiroyuki Tokumori, an prodigy who goes to Yukari’s school and was the object of her affections, and Arashi is known of that, which is why he’s insecure of that. Isabelle Yamamoto is the mother figure of Paradise Kiss and is the epitome of high class and femininity and also inspired George’s first dress during their childhood and often encourages Yukari when she needs it the most, whether it’s George or her studies. I don’t know if this is spoiler territory or not, but she happens to be a transgender woman.




If you already know, this is based off the manga series by AI Yazawa and it’s a stand-alone sequel to her previous work, Gokinjo Monogatari, although that manga or the anime isn’t in English. There is also the point that a 5-volume manga is only squashed into 12 episodes. I’m not complaining about that but it seemed like some parts of the anime may have either been rushed or forgotten.



The plot of the show isn’t what most people call ‘original’ but it’s not the same rehash of any other story you ever heard. The themes of the story are very realistic, along with the characters, and you feel like you actually know some characteristics of people in real life pursuing their dreams of doing (insert whatever you can think of, I wasn’t really interested in just the fashion part of the series).




The animation of the show is done by Madhouse (9th times the charm, isn’t it?) and it does show a lot of quality brand of animation around the time of 2005 and even if it’s been over 7 years since the release, the animation still holds up today and the one thing that does weird me out is the deformed looks of the characters once it’s shown and it is me, or does Yukari in her deformed mode looks like if Olive Oyl was an anime character? I’m serious about that.




The music really holds up well during the show, especially the opening and ending music. The opening theme, “Lonely in Gorgeous” by Tommy february6 has this funky vibe of J-Pop mixed in with ‘80s Madonna vogue music. “Do You Want to” by well-known British pop-band Franz Ferdinand, originally from their album You Could Have It So Much Better, and I like it how it always played off during the end of an episode that isn’t a clean cut to the end credits, plus, it’s an fairly awesome song to listen to. The background music is not really that noticeable throughout the show but it doesn’t stick out awkwardly.



FINAL VERDICT: Despite that I really don’t know much in the fashion world, I did enjoy this series in it’s entirely. The story is very compelling and doesn’t stray away for only one character as it covers basically all of them. This is the type of anime that focuses on realistic characters in realistic situations and do you know how people always say ‘we need a break of the norm’? Well, Paradise Kiss is the break of the anime norm.

Paradise Kiss is one of the few animes that deserve to be described as flawless. From the beautiful animation, to the heart-warming story, this series executes its purpose with effortless perfection.
Straddling between elements of realism and dream-like extravagance, Paradise Kiss pulls its viewer's into the life of a high school girl turned model. Although the premise may at first seem contrived, the storytelling transforms every girl's dream into a story of escaping routine and finding happiness.
For anyone and everyone who has ever felt trapped the routine boredom of everyday life, Yukari's feelings echo the secret wish to run away. Coupled with oddball characters, this normalhigh school student finds her own definition of living her life.\n\n
It's hard for me to rate any aspect of this show below a 10--from the fantastic animation and great voice acting to the masterful storytelling, Paradise Kiss is perfect. If you liked Nana, you'll love this short from Ai Yazawa.

One thing you can say is that Ai Yazawa's art is jaw-drop goregeous and this anime stays true to her creations. A quirky coming of age story, set against a backdrop of high fashion, the heroine "Caroline" (I can't remember her real name!) falls in love with her boss and designer, Gerorge, a free-spirit and artist. Using a stereotypical framework (girl rejects previous life for something completely different and more glamerous and finds love in the process), Paradise Kiss creates a whole new spin. Plus, the SD faces are unique and so funny.

I watched this anime because one of my friend recommended it to me. And when I look at the genre, I saw the Comedy and that makes me think like "Okay, it is a comedy. So let's give it a try" (I'm a fan of comedy genre). 
So, then I watched the anime. And I was like "Where's the comedy?" I mean, I can count how many time I laughed throughout the show. WTH? The Comedy genre is definitely out. Don't go and put the genre as Comedy if it only has several laughable scenes. As a comedy fan, it pissed me off.
Some other animelike Usagi Drop also has some comedy in it, but you don't put it as a comedy because it's not. So does Paradise Kiss..!


Also, I hate the main character's voice. What with her voice? She sounded so lame. She is supposed to be someone beautiful and repulsive, so the voice should be more lively and confident. Just hearing her voice makes me annoyed.


At the beginning of the anime, there were like some unnecessary stuffs. I don't even know what are those for. Just skipped to the part where the title is on.


For the male character, I don't have any feeling for him. Well, different people has different taste.


As conclusion, I won't recommend this to any of my friend. :o

Beautiful art, fashionable clothes, cool characters, interesting storyline focused on the relationships of the characters! Paradise kiss is one my favorites, although it's short it's worthy of your time.

I tried watching this a few years back and only got up to episode two before calling it quits. The only reason I went back and tried again was that I wanted to watch something similar to Nana. And I actually believed I could find an anime with a balance of story with actual intimacy without it being boring.
Sadly to say I didn't find what I was looking for.
I watched this dubbed but I'm sure watching it subbed wouldn't have mattered too much anyway. But for the dubbed version, the voice acting was so terrible that it took out any emotion they were trying toconvey.


Yukari was such a bitch I didn't see any growth in her. She was a teen with no identity and acted as a robot for her mom. But even when she rebelled she acted stupidly. The stupidest line in this entire anime from her was "There's no point in fishing high school if you're not going to go to college."


George didn't seem like a teen. He seemed much older. Not to say he was mature though. He was a jerk who tried to come off as cool but was just as boring to watching. I didn't see or feel any kind of chemistry between him and Yukari.


Miwako, like some characters, reminded me of characters from Nana, not surprise there, She reminded me of Misato. But Misato did not have an annoying, fake voice in the dubbed version and she came off as much more mature for a kid. Her relationship with Arashi was a little interesting but they didn't show as many scenes with them for me to care enough.


Arashi reminds me of Nobu, but of course, Nobu, like most of the Nana characters, are much more mature. This guy who ironically had safety pins for piercings was a typical, cliche jerk who happened to be the "voice of reason".


That Hiro guy was the most annoying busybody.


I feel like the anime had potential if it had gone a different route and had more episodes. But in the end, it just didn't work for me.

For us, teenagers who try to make their own life, there will be always problems with getting along with our parents, this anime may be something very interesting. 
Especially for the girls, who will discover in Caroline the wish to know herself better in order to discover the path to live her life. At this moment of uncertainty, comes George to fix up Caroline's thoughts. Or, to mixt them up? 
What it is clear: love makes great changes in a human's life, and Caroline is not an exception!!! Discover more by watching Paradise Kiss!!!
